questions.neutral: Is your night just starting or ending?

hobby.message: You bring something banned books with you again?
Freestyle FPV drones still keeping you sane?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I fly FPV drones. It's a way to escape the noise of the city.
neutral_answer: Just stopped by after flying drones for a bit.
Its a quick hobby, nothing major.
This referendum noise makes finding quiet air tricky lately.
Maybe I shouldve gone home instead.
Day's been a mix of work and flying my FPV drone.
That tram depot crowd after the vote messed with my signal.
Too many new pilots in the air these days.
I still managed to squeeze in a few minutes alone.
Can't stay out too long with all these changes.
It's somewhere in the middle. Had a drone session after work.
Freestyle FPV flying clears my head.
Lately, the city's too busy with referendum fallout to fly undisturbed.
Even spotted some protestors trying to livestream aerial shots.
Had to share frequencies, made things pretty unpredictable.
Still, nice to watch the city from above sometimes.
Honestly, night could go either way. Needed to reset after flying drones.
Freestyle FPV is my thing, especially industrial zones when they're quiet.
Last week, the referendum crowds hijacked all the best open spots.
Ended up flying with other pilots, sharing feeds to local organizers.
Never thought I'd be part of a civic broadcast, but things are shifting.
The old 'fly solo and vanish' routine doesn't work now.
Strange, but I'm getting used to it.
Night doesn't really start or end for me, not lately.
Spent hours flying my custom FPV drone past Sector Five.
I used to fly solo, off-grid—just for the sense of control.
With the referendum, people flooded my favorite spots, lots of noise and new faces.
Had to link my feed to some kid's crowd projector—completely new territory.
Honestly, navigating cross-signal chaos and frantic organizers was harder than any technical glitch.
But seeing how the city's changed up close, fast and unpredictable... it's like learning to read a new kind of current.
I still miss the silence, but maybe there's something good in having to adapt.
hobby_answer: Mostly analog.
Easier to swap out if interference spikes.
Blackout scrambled a lot of flights, so I keep backups.
I don’t fly during crowd surges anymore.
That’s it.
Analog now, digital if signal’s stable.
Last week’s rally scrambled every feed in the depot.
Too many new pilots in the air, some don’t know etiquette.
After that blackout, I doubled up on manual failsafes.
Flight windows are shorter with all this activity.
Not as relaxing lately.
Analog mostly. Less lag, real hands-on control.
Blackout messed up the local relay; lost video mid-flight.
Since the referendum, everyone’s in the air—protesters, some grassroots coalitions too.
Airspace is chaotic, more interference, less solitude now.
Had a kid ask to piggyback my stream—never happened before.
I still fly, just more careful with who’s watching.
Makes you rethink ‘off-grid.’
Analog. Digital gets noisy these days with all the cross-frequencies around.
Last week, depot was crowded with civic groups and pilots live-streaming rallies.
Used to fly solo, now it’s drones everywhere, everyone wants a feed.
Lost control for a second—someone else’s protest stream crossed my channel.
Had to share my feed to a coalition projector. Weird vibe, but interesting.
Feels like the city turned into a demo zone overnight.
After blackout, even backup gear’s not a guarantee.
Still, clearing my head with flight’s non-negotiable.
Analog first, digital for high altitudes—old habit from before wristband tracking.
I built my own receivers, keep them off-grid when I can.
The depot’s become a second home, but now it’s a meeting point for activists too.
During the shutdown, I fixed signals for pilots grounded by failed relays.
Saw grassroots groups organizing through shared drone feeds—never saw that before referendum.
A kid recognized my drone, asked to stream protest footage, so I patched him in.
Strange to surrender the frequency, but it felt… cooperative for once.
My hobby’s alone time was hijacked by the city, but maybe that’s not all bad.
Without BCI running, watching drones move in sync was the only order left.
